Table 2 MoPO loadings (wt%) Tmax1 (°C) Desorbed NH3 (μmol/g) Tmax2 (°C) Desorbed NH3 (μmol/g) Tmax3 (°C) Desorbed NH3 (μmol/g) Total Desorbed NH3 (mmol/g) 5 77 314 167 64 547 111 0.49 10 65 448 157 201 506 161 0.81 20 63 522 143 263 679 206 1.02 30 80 310 287 104 588 108 0.52 40 80 232 361 37 525 87 0.36 50 – – 152 28 469 79 0.11 Vapor phase esterification of levulinic acid catalyzed by γ-Al2O3 supported molybdenum phosphate catalysts Sailaja Gadamsetti Nagaraju Mathangi Sk. Hussain Vijay Kumar Velisoju Komandur V.R. Chary ⁎ Catalysis Division, Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, 500 007, India Catalysis Division Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Hyderabad 500 007 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A comprehensive comparison of the catalytic activities of alumina supported molybdenum phosphate (MoPO) catalysts with different loadings of MoPO was investigated in the vapor phase esterification of levulinic acid (LA) with ethanol (EtOH) to synthesize ethyl levulinate (EL). The catalysts were characterized by various techniques to find the surface and structural properties. The esterification reaction parameters such as MoPO loading on Al2O3, molar ratio of EtOH/LA, reaction temperature and reaction time were optimized. Raman and FT-IR studies confirmed the formation of pyrophosphate phase on alumina. XRD results revealed the presence of well dispersed MoPO species over alumina support. The esterification activity of these catalysts mainly depends on the number of acidic sites and dispersion of MoPO species. Keywords Molybdenum phosphate Alumina Levulinic acid Ethyl levulinate 1 Introduction Depletion of reserves of fossil fuels and increasing global energy consumption leads to the development of alternative renewable resources. In this context, a great deal of research is currently devoted worldwide in pursuit of lignocellulosic biomass and its derivatives to produce energy, chemicals and fuels [1–5]. Ethyl levulinate (EL), one of the current biodiesel sources, can be obtained by catalytic ethanolysis of renewable levulinic acid (LA). Levulinic acid has drawn a significant attention as a renewable, most promising platform molecule for its two active groups such as a ketone and a carboxylic acid and it can be easily derived by acid treatment of abundantly available bio resources like cellulose. LA is a versatile building block in various synthesis routes for production of value added chemicals such as acrylic acid, γ-valerolactone, α-angelica lactone, 3-hydroxypropionic acid, levulinate esters and 1, 4-pentanediol [6,7]. Among these explorations, esterification of LA with EtOH has received a great deal of attention as green process for ethyl levulinate production. Due to low toxicity, flash point stability, lubricity, and moderate flow properties under low temperature conditions, ethyl levulinate has been marked as a promising chemical platform for utilization in various applications in fragrance and flavoring industry. Ethyl levulinate have shown better solubility in gasoline than other alkyl levulinates such as butyl levulinate and methyl levulinate. Therefore, EL is considered as an excellent octane booster for gasoline, used as cold flow improvers in biodiesel and used as diesel miscible bio-fuel in diesel car engines [8–11]. The origin of green chemistry principles and due to environmental problems, efforts have recently made in order to design recyclable solid acid catalysts to replace toxic and corrosive homogenous acids. Thus, cleaner technology could be facilitating by use of environment friendly heterogeneous catalysts. In this area of research, Nandiwale et al. studied the liquid phase esterification of LA with EtOH using dodecatungstophosphoricacid on desilicated H-ZSM-5 and achieved 94% LA conversion and 100% EL selectivity [12]. Amberlyst −15 and sulphated SnO2 showed high conversion of LA among the catalysts tested for liquid phase esterification of LA with EtOH by Fernandez et al. which was probably due to strong acidity [13]. In addition, various types of solid acid catalysts such as sulfated Si-doped ZrO2 [14], sulfonic mesostructured silicas [15] have been investigated for esterification of LA with EtOH. The majority of the past studies have been reported in the liquid phase under batch conditions. Whereas, the present study deals with the solid acid catalyzed (MoPO/Al2O3) levulinic acid conversion to ethyl levulinate in the vapor conditions at atmospheric pressure. Molybdenum is usually supported on TiO2, SiO2, Al2O3, and ZrO2 to improve catalytic activity and mechanical strength. The surface structures of these supported molybdenum catalysts are quite different from that of bulk molybdenum catalyst. Molybdenum based catalysts used in both environmental catalysis and in the petrochemical industry such as combustion of soot, hydrodesulphurization reactions, dehydrogenation of alkanes, oxidation of methanol, and olefins metathesis [16–18]. Notably, from the application point of view, metal phosphates are the most interesting species for stabilization of metal in different oxidation states and also for its acidic properties. This acidic behavior can be attributed to surface POH groups and coordinately unsaturated metal ions exposed on the surface coupled to MO double bonds. Molybdenum phosphorus oxides (MoPO) are mainly reported as new cathode material for lithium and sodium batteries [19]. Alumina-supported molybdenum oxide catalysts are familiar in various catalytic processes such as esterification of acetic acid, benzylation of anisole and isomerization of α-pinene [20,21]. Recently, Mitran et al. have reported that alumina-supported molybdenum was able to catalyze the esterification reaction and showing selectivity of 100% for n-butyl acetate at 81% conversion of acetic acid [22]. Oxidative dehydrogenation reaction was carried out with alumina supported molybdenum catalysts which were modified by vanadium and phosphorous. In this work, Haddad et al. observed that there is an increase in conversion of ethane when molybdenum based catalysts are modified with phosphorous [23]. To the best of our knowledge, metal phosphate catalysts have been never employed earlier for esterification reactions. The aim of this work is to evaluate the catalytic properties of the alumina supported MoPO catalysts and its contribution to esterification of LA with EtOH to ethyl levulinate (Scheme 1 ). The reaction parameters such as loadings of MoPO on alumina, molar ratio between EtOH and LA, reaction temperature and reaction time were optimized. The catalysts were characterized by N2-sorption analysis, Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), Raman spectroscopy and powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) methods. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The procedure for the preparation of molybdenum phosphate (MoPO) is described elsewhere [24,25]. A 250 mL round bottom flask fitted with a reflux condenser was first charged with 7.5 g of MoO3 (99.5%, Aldrich) and 22.5 cm3 85% H3PO4 (331 mmol, Aldrich) at approximately 180 °C. The mixture was stirred for1.5 h and allowed to cool down to room temperature. To this solution, 200 cm3 of 15.8 M HNO3 (Fisher) was added and refluxed further for 12 h. Upon cooling, the white Mo containing material was precipitated from the solution. The target solid part was filtered off from the liquid by vacuum-filtration washed with acetone and dried in air. This prepared material was calcined in a furnace at 550 °C (5 °C/min) for 6 h. A series of MoPO/Al2O3catalysts with different MoPO loadings in the range of 5–50 wt% were prepared by wet impregnation method.γ-Al2O3, used as the support was procured from Engelhard Corporation. The supported MoPO/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation of a solution containing MoPO on Al2O3 support at 60 °C. These Al2O3 supported MoPO samples were dried at 110 °C for 16 h and subsequently calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in a muffle furnace. The as-prepared catalyst samples were denoted as x wt% MoPO/Al2O3, where x denotes the MoPO weight content on γ-Al2O3 support. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the samples pressed in KBr pellets were collected on an IR (Model: GC-FT-IR Nicolet 670) spectrometer. The Raman spectra of the catalyst samples were done with a Horbia Jobin Yvon Lab Ram HR spectrometer. The nitrogen adsorption−desorption isotherms were collected from Autosorb-1 (Quanta chrome instruments), and the specific surface area, pore size distribution studies (PSD) of the synthesized catalysts calculated by the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method. Degree of crystallinity was observed via X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANCE, Germany) Ultima-IV X-ray diffractometer (M/s. Rigaku Corporation, Japan). TPD experiments were conducted on AutoChem 2910 instrument. In a typical TPD experiment, 100 mg of sample was supported on quartz wool in U shaped tube and pre heated at 420 °C for 1 h and saturated with highly pure anhydrous ammonia with a mixture of 10% NH3–He at 80 °C for 1 h. After adsorption of NH3, the sample was flushed with He flow (50 mL min−1) at 100 °C for 1 h to remove physisorbed ammonia. TPD experiment was performed from ambient temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10°/min. The amount of NH3 desorbed was calculated using GRAMS/32 software. 2.3 Catalytic reaction Esterification of levulinic acid with EtOH experiments were performed in a down flow fixed bed quartz reactor operating at atmospheric pressure. In a typical experiment, 0.3 g of the catalyst along with equal weight of glass beads were charged into the reactor and were supported on a glass wool bed and flushed at 250 °C under N2 flow for 1 h with a GHSV of 1.27 mL gcat −1 s−1. A different ratio of LA and EtOH were injected by means of B-Braun syringe pump and was vaporized in a preheating zone provided on the top of the catalyst bed. The reaction was carried out in the range of 250–300 °C. The products were collected periodically every hour under ice cooled trap and analyzed using an HP 6890 gas chromatograph equipped with FID using an HP-5 column and confirmed by HP GC 5973 MSD instrument using a HP-1MS column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis The N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was carried out to measure the textural properties of alumina supported molybdenum phosphate (MoPO) catalysts (Fig. 1 ). The surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of the samples were also given in Table 1 . Pure alumina has BET surface area of 288 m2 g−1. It is evident from Table 1 that MoPO loading influence the structural properties of MoPO/Al2O3 catalysts. The surface area of supported catalysts decreased from 251 to 57 m2/g with the increase in MoPO loading from 5 to 50 wt% on Al2O3. There is a sudden drop of surface area observed from 20 wt% to 30 wt% MoPO loadings (Table 1) which is mostly due to the blockage of pores by MoPO species. All catalysts exhibited an average peak pore diameters in the range 30–70 A° (Table 1). 3.2 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectra of representative samples are provided in Fig. 2 in the region of 400–1200 cm−1 that was maintained in an ambient environment. The appearance of band in the region of 900–1000 cm−1 is observed at higher MoPO loading (>30 wt%). This band can be assigned to asymmetric stretching frequency of PO4 3− group which confirms the formation of molybdenum phosphate phase on alumina. The other band at 825 cm−1 is exhibited by higher MoPO loading of 50 wt% due to the stretching frequency of MoOMo bond. These findings confirm the formation of polymolybdate structure over the surface of Al2O3 at higher MoPO loadings due to agglomeration of MoPO species [26]. 3.3 Powder X-ray diffraction analysis To examine the crystallinity of the catalytic samples, XRD analysis was performed and the patterns are presented in Fig. 3 . The pure MoPO sample exhibits main reflection at 2θ = 22° and 28.1°. The XRD pattern of γ −Al2O3 showed three reflections at 2θ = 37.2°, 45.6° and 66.9° which coincide with database standard (JCPDS No. 10-0425). As the metal phosphate loading increases on the alumina, the intensity of XRD peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 45.6° and 66.9° decreased. At higher loadings (50 wt% MoPO/Al2O3), new peaks noticed due to agglomerisation of MoPO species at 2θ = 22.2° and 28.1°. The absence of these peaks at lower loadings indicates the well dispersion of MoPO species over alumina. However, MoPO species crystalline size of lower loadings might be less than 4 nm, which is beyond the detection range of the XRD technique. 3.4 FT- IR spectroscopy To further investigate the structural properties of the catalysts, the FT-IR spectra of pure alumina support and different loading of MoPO ranging from 5 to 50 wt% supported on alumina were shown in Fig. 4 . The FT-IR spectra of pure MoPO sample shows the IR bands at 3600, 1620,1251, 1124, 1025, 928, 858 cm−1 and 738 cm−1. In the FT-IR spectrum of alumina, the broad absorption band at 3300–3700 cm−1 and at around 1650 cm−1 observed due to stretching and bending vibrations of surface OH groups respectively. The peaks in the absorption range of 500–1000 cm−1 were assigned to AlO (782 and 691 cm−1) vibrations [27]. For alumina supported MoPO catalysts, apart from main characteristic peaks of alumina, additional peaks were observed at 1124, 928, 858 and 727 cm−1. The additional peak intensities increase with increase in MoPO loading. The other two bands at 1124 and 858 cm−1 are attributed to symmetric vibration (ν s) and asymmetric vibration (ν as) of PO bonds in PO4 −3 group. The bands also observed at 727 and 928 cm−1 assigned to ν s and ν as of POP bonds respectively which confirms the formation of molybdenum pyrophosphate on alumina. 3.5 Temperature programmed desorption of NH3 TPD is one of the important techniques to estimate the acidic strength and amount of acidic sites of the catalysts, using ammonia as a probe molecule. TPD profiles of pure alumina and MoPO/Al2O3 catalyst were shown in Fig. 5 and total ammonia desorbed values were presented in Table 2 . The TPD results of all catalyst samples show a broad peak at low temperature, which corresponds to weak acidic region. With an increase in MoPO loading from 5 to 20 wt%, the intensity of additional peak in the moderate acidic region also observed till 20 wt% MoPO loading. Further increase in MoPO loading, decrease in peak intensity is observed in both week and moderate acidic region. From Fig. 5, it is clearly seen that the area under desorption peaks for 20 wt% MoPO/Al2O3 sample is much higher than other alumina supported MoPO catalysts. Therefore, the total amount of acid sites and also number of moderate acidic sites of 20 wt% MoPO/Al2O3 is high than other loadings which are found to exhibit better activity compared to other samples [28]. The TPD results demonstrated that the acidity of the supported catalysts strongly influenced by the variation of MoPO loading. Thus, the drop of acidity of higher loadings (>30 wt% MoPO/Al2O3) is caused by aggregation of MoPO species, which may block the pores of alumina support. The catalytic activity results of alumina supported MoPO catalysts are in good agreement with the total acidity results acquired from TPD of NH3. 3.6 Catalytic activity results 3.6.1 Effect of MoPO loading on alumina A detailed study was investigated with an aim to explore the catalytic properties of MoPO/Al2O3 catalysts for the esterification of LA with EtOH. Usually, the vapor phase esterification of LA with EtOH yields EL as a major product along with γ-valerolactone (GVL) and α-angelica lactone (AAL) as minor products, which depend on molar ratio of EtOH:LA, reaction temperature and reaction time. Fig. 6 shows detailed view of ethanolysis of LA over pure alumina and various loadings of MoPO/Al2O3 catalysts. A blank reaction (without catalyst) was also carried out and negligible LA conversion was observed. Pure MoPO has shown 11% of LA conversion with 34% selectivity of EL and 66% selectivity of AAL probably due to less acidity confirmed by NH3-TPD, whereas the conversion of LA was high for all alumina supported MoPO catalysts irrespective of MoPO loadings. Higher LA conversion over alumina supported MoPO than pure MoPO is attributed to the increase in acidity and BET surface area of catalysts. From Fig. 6, one can notice that the conversion of LA increased with an increase in MoPO loading from 5 to 20 wt%. Decrease in LA conversion at higher MoPO loading (>30 wt%) from 100% to 75% was observed. The selectivity of EL increased from 70 to 99% with an increase in MoPO loading from 5 to 20 wt% and decreased to 82% at higher MoPO loadings. Higher LA conversion to EL over 20 wt% MoPO/Al2O3 suggested that the acidic strength and dispersion of MoPO could significantly affect the product selectivity. It can be seen from Fig. 6, the decrease in the conversion of LA may have been partly owing to aggregation of MoPO species and also due to less acidity of the catalyst, which is clearly observed from NH3-TPD. The catalytic experiments were also carried out with pure alumina under similar reaction conditions, which showed 70% of LA conversion and 40% of EL selectivity. 3.6.2 Effect of ethanol: levulinic acid molar ratio The influence of EtOH: LA molar ratio was evaluated in the range of 2:1–10:1 using the catalyst 20 wt% MoPO/Al2O3 catalyst at 250 °C. Ethanolysis of LA is a reversible reaction and is well-known from the Le Chatelier’s principle that the large amount of EtOH favors the formation of EL [29]. Increase in EtOH: LA ratio from 2:1 to 8:1, selectivity of EL and conversion of LA was increased as shown in Fig. 7 . The LA conversion of 100% was achieved at EtOH: LA molar ratio of 8:1. Conversion was not significantly altered with further increase in molar ratio of EtOH to LA from 8:1 to 10:1 but decrease in the EL selectivity is observed. GVL was also detected during the esterification of LA at molar ratio of EtOH: LA = 10:1, since excess EtOH act as hydrogen source trough Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) mechanism. Dehydration of LA forms AAL and the formation of diethyl ether occurs due to inter molecular dehydration of EtOH which found to be the main reasons for the decrease in EL selectivity at higher molar ratio of EtOH to LA. 3.6.3 Effect of reaction temperature The reaction was carried out at different experiments in order to examine the effect of reaction temperature over the 20 wt% MoPO/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 8 ). The reaction temperature varied over a range of 250–300 °C. Notably, an increase in temperature from 250 to 300 °C had a negative effect on selectivity of EL. Formation of various undesired products such as AAL and GVL was observed with the increase in temperature from 250 to 300 °C. Therefore, the optimal reaction temperature to perform the ethanolysis of LA is found to be 250 °C, which is near to the boiling point of LA. 3.6.4 Time on stream The stability and catalytic performance of 20 wt% MoPO/Al2O3 has been investigated for esterification of LA with EtOH as a function of reaction time and the results presented in Fig. 9 . The formation of EL was high (99%) at the beginning of the reaction but exhibited a decreasing trend after 20 h of time and reached to 93% at 75 h. However, formation of GVL and AAL was observed with increase in time. This little deactivation can be explained in terms of carbon deposition (∼2 wt%) on the surface of 20 wt% MoPO/Al2O3 catalyst which is attributed to the irreversible chemisorption of other undesired products such as AAL and GVL [30]. The results demonstrated that the conversion of LA is 85% and selectivity of EL is 93% even after 75 h indicating the catalyst stability under the experimental conditions adopted for the esterification LA with EtOH to EL. The used 20MoPO/Al2O3 catalyst (after 75 h) was characterized using XRD and the results are compared with the fresh form of the catalyst (Fig. S1). The results obtained in this analysis indicated insignificant differences between fresh and used forms of the 20MoPO/Al2O3 catalyst. 4 Conclusions Al2O3 supported MoPO catalysts prepared and tested in the vapor phase esterification of levulinic acid to ethyl levulinate at atmospheric pressure. All the alumina supported catalysts shown better results than pure MoPO and pure alumina as catalysts. Among the different catalysts tested for esterification of LA with EtOH, 20 wt% MoPO/Al2O3 showed the best catalytic results towards LA conversion and EL selectivity. The results of catalytic tests indicated the importance of acidic sites, structural properties of the catalysts and effect of dispersion in the esterification reaction between LA and EtOH. The high activity of 20wt% MoPO/Al2O3 catalyst is attributed to the presence of high number of strong acidic sites compared to the other catalysts tested and is found to be stable for 75 h of continuous operation with a small decrease in the activity. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2018.01.011. coredata.dc:description: A comprehensive comparison of the catalytic activities of alumina supported molybdenum phosphate (MoPO) catalysts with different loadings of MoPO was investigated in the vapor phase esterification of levulinic acid (LA) with ethanol (EtOH) to synthesize ethyl levulinate (EL). The catalysts were characterized by various techniques to find the surface and structural properties. The esterification reaction parameters such as MoPO loading on Al2O3, molar ratio of EtOH/LA, reaction temperature and reaction time were optimized. Raman and FT-IR studies confirmed the formation of pyrophosphate phase on alumina. XRD results revealed the presence of well dispersed MoPO species over alumina support. The esterification activity of these catalysts mainly depends on the number of acidic sites and dispersion of MoPO species.
coredata.dc:title: Vapor phase esterification of levulinic acid catalyzed by γ-Al2O3 supported molybdenum phosphate catalysts
coredata.prism:issueName: Metal Oxides in Catalysis - Professor Benjaram M. Reddy Festschrift
